title: 📦 Installation
text:
VIMuRe is available in both R and Python. The R implementation is a wrapper around the Python implementation. Both packages are in active development and are not yet on CRAN or PyPI. Use the installation instructions below to install the latest development version.

RPython


Step 01: install reticulate with the following command:
install.packages("reticulate")






Click here to learn more about reticulate






Our core code is written in python, so we use reticulate to integrate our model in R. This package allows you to use Python within your R session in a seamless, high-performance interoperable way.
reticulate will look for python installed in your computer. If, for some reason, it cannot find it, you may be prompted to download and install miniconda.

Miniconda is the recommended installation method for most users, as it is easier to ensure that the newly installed python is isolated from other python installs you have in your system.
If you initially declined the miniconda installation prompt, you can later manually install miniconda by running reticulate::install_miniconda().





Step 02: install vimure==0.1 with the following command:
require(devtools)
devtools::install_github("latentnetworks/vimure", subdir="src/R", ref="develop")
Step 03: Finally, you must install the Python package as well. This is because the R package is a wrapper around the Python package. To install the Python package, follow the instructions below.
require(vimure)
vimure::install_vimure()
If you are not using RStudio, i.e. you are using R in the terminal, you may need to restart your R session after installing the Python package.
Step 04: To confirm that the installation was successful, run the following command:
library(vimure)
vimure::vm_config()
You should see something like the following:
#> Loaded vimure version
#> Vimure v (...)
#> Python v3.x (...)


Install vimure==0.1 with the following command:
pip install "git+https://github.com/latentnetworks/vimure.git#egg=vimure&subdirectory=src/python/"
This Python package was tested on Python >= 3.6 and it is expect to work fine in all OSes.
Read more about the Python set up for development here.

title: 💻 Quick Start
text:
Here, we’ll illustrate how to use Vimure to model social networks from a village in Karnataka, India, gathered as part of a project studying the adoption of microfinance (Banerjee et al 2013). The data files we use here are derived from those openly-available on the Harvard Dataverse page.
We have selected a particular village and read in its edgelist. This contains information on multiple different types of relationships. Our interest here is on relationships that were “double-sampled” in the original survey, i.e. elicited through two different prompts. For example, respondents were asked both “If you needed to borrow kerosene or rice, to whom would you go?” as well as “Who would come to you if he/she needed to borrow kerosene or rice?” Four different relationship types (or “layers”) were double-sampled in this way (i.e., were elicited with two prompt types).
The code below will preprocess the data, removing self-loops and creating new labels to represent the four relationship type or “layers” joining together the two prompt types. Here, we’ll select one of these layers to consider (the “visit” layer resulting from the “visitgo” and “visitcome” prompts).

title: 💻 Quick Start
text:
Import required libraries

library(vimure)
library(dplyr)
library(readr)

title: 💻 Quick Start
text:
Load the data


Code
village <- "12" # change this parameter to run in other village

URL <- paste0("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/latentnetworks/vimure/develop",
              "/data/input/india_microfinance/formatted/",
              paste0("vil", village, "_edges.csv"))
df_edges <- read_csv(URL)
head(df_edges)


# A tibble: 6 × 5
  respondent       i       j type        weight
       <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>
1    1200101 1200101 1202101 borrowmoney      1
2    1200102 1200102 1200402 borrowmoney      1
3    1200201 1200201 1207901 borrowmoney      1
4    1200202 1200202 1216002 borrowmoney      1
5    1200801 1200801 1200601 borrowmoney      1
6    1200802 1200802 1200901 borrowmoney      1

title: VIMuRe
text: (🚧 This is a work in progress. 🚧)

title: VIMuRe
text:
📝 In brief

Input: multiply-sampled social network data as a list of adjacency matrices or igraph objects. 1
Output: a fitted latent network model that can be used to obtain samples or a point-estimate network (an igraph object) from the posterior distribution of the fitted model. 2
